comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content:
Tiny desk and very small typewriter for the woman in the background.
Was wondering if maybe it wasn't a typewriter but some sort of adding machine. Looks very narrow.
That rug looks like it's been there for donkey's years, and the new fluorescent tubes are jury-rigged from the old light fittings.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] Still think it's a typewriter, just a portable one - see the lid of the case?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I think it's just a small travel typewriter, a bit like this

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I think the phone has it's own desk because there's only one phone for the whole office. I think the closer woman is senior, she is older, has a bigger desk and no typewriter. The younger lady has a tiny desk and a typewriter: she does the job a laser printer would do today.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: We had a black Bakelite phone with braided cables like that at home, when I was little in the 60s.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: It is a "portable typewriter" and the equivalent of the modern laptop, I used one for years.  They were generally taken from the case when in use but could be used as illustrated.  There may have been another person to woman the phone or even a part time person.  Interesting comparing the proliferation of phones in a modern office with those days!

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] We had a portable Underwood at home when I was young. Actually, it's still there.
The one in this picture looks particularly small, especially given the size of it's case.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: 22 Herbert Street, Dublin maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,716836,733119,7,3 Google Street View maps.google.co.uk/maps?q=%2222+Herbert+Street%22+Dublin&a... Today it seems to be multiple-occupation recording studios. Anybody got a 1965 street directory handy?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] I do! I do! Checked Thoms Dublin Directories for the 1960s here at Library Towers.
1965 shows J.A. Doyle, F.R.I.A.I., architect; and Nicholas O'Dwyer, Consulting Engineers.
1967 shows J.A. Doyle still there and also Clensol Ltd.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: O'Dea is more of a Consulting Engineer photographer than an Architect photographer, wouldn't you say?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Would think so! But hopefully either company name may help us find out who the women are...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
